Author: adopter010

Comment: Untrue -- Social Security is mostly a "pay as you go" system. Each year, a bunch of people who are working pay a bunch of taxes; that money is then paid out to the beneficiaries. The "mostly" part is that thanks to the baby boom, we've got a "hump" of retirees. Because this was totally foreseeable, we paid extra into the system to generate a mound of extra money.  Per the social security trustee projections, once the chunk of extra money we saved up is gone, the incoming money is enough to pay for about 78% of the promised amount. But, social security is a super popular program, and the chances that it won't be saved is about 0%. There's a bunch of proposed ways to ensure people get their promised benefits.  The only way you won't get money is if the entire economy is completely hosed for decades. And if that happens, there's no realistic "plan B" for most people. Personally, I don't think that will happen: America has far too many smart, driven people with a diverse set of skills, plus amazingly productive farmland, and all hte minerals you can shake a stick at.

Author: sedatedlife

Comment: Ugh here we go again, someone with strong opinions about something that have a fundamental misunderstand of how it works.   Here's the one stat you need to know;  if there were zero changes to social security, when you retire you would receive 83% of what you would receive if you retired right now.  I implore you to do your own research, but basically SS ran a surplus on what it collected versus what it paid out for a number of years.  Sometime in the last 30 years, that equation flipped and the money they built up during the surplus is making up for that deficit.  Once that runs out, which is projected to happen in ~10 years, then the program can only use the money it takes in to pay out.  And without changes, that means a reduction to 83% of current benefits.   Unless they intend to pay me back the money I've contributed at this point, I'd much rather get that 83% than have the program eliminated entirely because it's misunderstood.

Comment: Here's a problem with increasing the income limt: it creates an obligation to pay benefits based on that income in the future. Calculating the primary insurance amount (PIA) uses three "bend points" where your average indexed monthly earnings (AIME) contribute different amounts to your benefits.  This is made up, but should show the point. .Suppose that the form of the equation used to calculate your benefits is:  90% of AIME up to $1000 per month plus  25% of AIME between $1000 per month and $5000 per month plus  15% for all AIME above $5000 per month.  Suppose that I have $10000 in AIME.,My PIA, not including any reduction for claiming benefits early,  is $900 plus $1000 plus $750. or $2650 per month.  We pay only 6.2% of income (12.4% counting the employer contribution.  Now apply the formula to someone with $105,000 in AIME where there is no limit on income on the amount sunject to FICA tax. They would get $900 plus $1000 plus $15,000, or $16,900 monthly, which is more than the employer and employee contributions when they were working.  *I hope that this points out the need to add more bend poinrs where one accrues only 1, 2 or 5  percent of AIME in benefits if you want to uncap the earnings limit.*

Comment: Not the same person you were answering, but while we're lifting the contribution limit, I feel we should also set a maximum benefit. We seem to have no problem setting maximum benefits for other programs. Unemployment insurance, for example, has a maximum payout regardless of income. My wife was laid off in the fall and the benefit was less than half of her previous income.   Maybe create some formula based on median income and peg it as the maximum. Try to make sure it's a reasonably liveable number. Keep the bend points and add "up to a maximum benefit of $X".

Author: No_Anxiety285

Comment: The purpose of having the extra bend points is to come close to setting a maximum benefit without actually capping it. Social Security isn't an investment program ,but a insurance program.  The current replacement rate of Social Security is about 40% of your final income, presuming that you retire at full retirement age or older. If you retire at 62, it will be about 28% of final income. This will drop to about 30% and 23% once the special purpose bonds that  Social Security holds have been sold off.
